I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In December 2011, during the country programming mission, the Government of the 
People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  requested  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  technical 
assistance (TA) for (i) strengthening the integration of public asset management and budget 
management; (ii) as a pilot case study for the first component, developing a public finance policy 
framework for the water resource management system; (iii) supporting the development of 
accounting services contributing to better public asset management and budget management; 
and (iv) developing knowledge products related to these three components. The 16–18 July 
2012 fact-finding mission reached an understanding with the government on the TA impact, 
outcome, outputs, cost estimates, financing plan, implementation arrangements, and terms of 
reference for consulting services. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Strengthen the integration of public asset management and budget management. 
Public asset management and budget management should be priority areas for fiscal reform in 
the PRC. Key public assets include public properties as a result of public investment, such as 
government  buildings,  vehicles,  office  equipment,  road  and  other  public  infrastructure;  and 
public resources such as forest, land, water resources etc. Budget management in this context  
refers to budget planning and preparation, as well as monitoring of budget implementation. 
While the government has implemented a number of fiscal reform measures, progress has 
focused  more  on  revenue  than  the  budgeting  process.  The  budgeting  process  is  still 
incremental, with more emphasis on expenditures than public asset management. Lack of a 
public asset management perspective in the budgeting process can lead to problems, such as 
improper use and maintenance of public properties.  
 
3.  Effective public asset management is becoming more important in the PRC as the 
government is expanding its infrastructure investment program to increase domestic demand in 
the midst of the global economic downturn, and to achieve balanced growth between central 
and western region and coastal areas. If the investment is implemented efficiently, it can benefit 
(i) the PRC by increasing its potential for future economic growth and (ii) the global economy by 
increasing demand that neighboring countries can rely on for their economic turnaround. If the 
investment is not managed appropriately, it could damage long-term fiscal soundness and thus 
impose greater risk on the global economy. 
 
4.  To maximize efficiency in utilizing public properties and public resources, the public 
asset  management  system  should  cover  the  whole  process  of  acquisition,  operation, 
maintenance, and disposal of public assets. In addition, as the central government has to 
delegate a significant portion of public asset management activities to local governments, it 
should strengthen monitoring and assessment of local government performance. For this, the 
central government needs to establish  a centralized registrar of public assets, develop an 
effective  monitoring  system  using  up-to-date  information  technology,  carry  out  regular 
assessment of the performance of local governments, and incorporate assessment results into 
the budgeting process. 
 
5.  Against this backdrop, the government aims to strengthen public asset management and 
eventually integrate public asset management with budget management. The finance minister 
recently stated an intention to strengthen the integration of public asset management and

budget management, and proposed that the relationship between public assets and budget 
expenditures should be carefully considered that the information about the value of public 
assets  will  be  fully  taken  account  of  for  the  whole  cycle  of  budget  management.  The 
government  is  attempting  to  develop  a  holistic  approach  covering  both  budget  and  asset 
management. This includes (i) establishing a standard public asset management framework, (ii) 
developing an information system for effective public asset management, and (iii) integrating 
public asset management with budget management. 
 
6.  Develop a public finance policy framework for the water resource management 
system.  In  the  PRC,  water  has  become  an  increasingly  scarce  resource  due  to  rapid 
industrialization  and  climate  change.  Problems  such  as  water  shortages,  pollution,  and 
ecological degradation have become major constraints to sustainable development. To address 
these  problems,  the  government  issued  the  Decision  on  Accelerating  Water  Management 
Reform in January 2011 and the Opinions on the Stringent Water Management System in 
February 2012.  
 
7.  The government expects that the water management will achieve four major goals in 
2020:  (i)  flood  control,  drought  relief,  and  disaster  alleviation;  (ii)  optimized  allocation  and 
effective utilization of water resources; (iii) protection of water resources and enhancement of 
ecological sustainability; and (iv) scientific development of water resources. To achieve these 
goals, the government will focus on three areas: (i) establish the macro-level water resource 
management system based on the projection of total water consumption, (ii) set up the micro-
level management system for efficient water resource use, and (iii) improve the water pollution 
control system. 
 
8.  To  implement  the  water  resource  management  system  successfully,  a  fiscal  policy 
framework must be established to generate and properly manage sufficient fiscal resources. 
The government is emphasizing the improvement of the overall water resource investment 
mechanism, which includes the management of funds to operate the water management system 
and  promote  water-saving  technology.  The  process  of  the  budget  allocation  for  water 
management will be based on the integrated framework of public asset management and 
budget management developed under the first component. 
 
9.  Support development of accounting services. Since 2005, the PRC accounting and 
auditing  standards  have  converged  substantially  with  the  International  Financial  Reporting 
Standards (IFRS) and International Standards on Auditing. A 2009 World Bank report indicated 
that the Chinese Accounting Standards and IFRS became basically comparable.2 In addition, 
significant progress has been made in certified public accountancy, partly supported by TA 
grants from ADB.3 
 
10.  Nevertheless, gaps still need to be filled to make PRC accounting services consistent 
with  other  leading  world  markets.  First,  discrepancies  between  the  Chinese  Accounting 
Standards  and the  IFRS,  such  as  the reversal  of  impairment  losses,  must  be  addressed. 
Second, the professional expertise of certified public accountants needs to be enhanced to 
ensure better compliance with the Chinese Standards on Auditing across auditing firms.

11.  The government has adopted policies to tackle these issues. The Ministry of Finance 
(MOF) issued the Roadmap for Continuing and Achieving Full Convergence of the Chinese 
Accounting Standards for Business Enterprises with IFRS on 2 April 2010. The government has 
implemented various policy measures to develop institutional capacity in accounting services, 
including issuing the Circular of the General Office of the State Council on Distributing the 
Opinions  of  the  Ministry  of  Finance  on  Accelerating  the  Development  of  Certified  Public 
Accountants. Such steps are beneficial to the development of accounting services and to the 
facilitation of free trade and market opening in the services sector. Both domestic and foreign 
investors may increase their investments, particularly in service industries, based on enhanced 
confidence in the PRC economy brought about by improved confidence in financial statements. 
For the government itself, strengthened accounting services will also contribute to better public 
asset management and budget management. Accordingly, the government plans to develop a 
policy  roadmap  for  (i)  opening  up  accounting  services;  (ii)  strengthening  its  international 
competitiveness; and (iii) promoting international cooperation in the supervision and market 
development of accounting services. 
 
12.  The TA is closely in aligned with ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2011–2015 for the 
PRC, which identifies good governance and capacity development as comprising one of four 
key drivers of change.4 To help achieve good governance, ADB will support government efforts 
to strengthen the policy, legal, fiduciary, and regulatory frameworks and practices to (i) improve 
delivery and management of infrastructure and public services, and (ii) promote the enabling 
environment for private sector development. The TA will support the government in improving 
the sustainable delivery and management of infrastructure services such as water resource 
management,  as  well  as  public  services  such  as  asset  management.  It  will  also  provide 
assistance to develop accounting services, which is critical to private sector development. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The impact of the TA will be improved efficiency in utilizing public assets, effective 
utilization of water resources, and strengthened competitiveness of accounting services. The TA 
outcome will be integration of public asset management and budget management process, 
effective public finance policy framework for the water resource management, and adherence to 
international standards of accounting services in the PRC. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities  
14.  The TA will help the government (i) improve fiscal management through strengthening 
the integration of public asset management and budget management; (ii) develop a public 
finance  policy  framework  for  the  water  resource  management  system;  and  (iii)  support 
development of accounting services by strengthening market competitiveness and enhancing 
international  cooperation  for  supervision  and  market  development.  For  each  of  the  three 
components, the TA will conduct an international case study to identify lessons from countries 
that have already developed good practices. Based on results from international studies and 
review  of  the  national  situation,  the  TA  will  develop  policy  recommendations  for  each 
component. Finally, the TA will arrange opportunities for staff capacity development such as 
international seminars and international study tours.

15.  The TA will deliver four major outputs: 
 
(i)  A study on strengthening the integration of public asset management and 
budget management. The TA will conduct the following activities: (a) analyze the 
current status of budget management in the PRC, (b) review international best 
practice in integrating public asset management and budget management, and (c) 
provide policy advice on improving public asset management. The final outputs 
will  be  three  policy  reports  on  (a)  reforming  public  asset  management,  (b) 
developing an information system for effective public asset management, and (c) 
integrating public asset management and budget management. 
 
(ii)  A  public  finance  policy  framework  for  the  water  resource  management 
system. The TA will conduct an international case study on the fiscal aspects of 
effective water resource management. Based on the study, the TA will provide 
policy recommendations for implementing public finance policies for the water 
resource  management  system.  The  recommendations  will  include  securing 
sufficient financial resources, managing funds properly, and implementing various 
water-saving  technology  programs.  The  process  of  the  budget  allocation  for 
water management will be based on the integrated framework of public asset 
management and budget management developed under the first component. The 
TA will produce a report on developing the public finance policy framework for the 
water resource management system. 
 
(iii)  Support for development of accounting services. The TA will support the 
government in developing policies for (a) opening up accounting services; (b) 
strengthening the competitiveness of accounting services, including accelerating 
the professional development of certified public accountants in the PRC; and (c) 
promoting international cooperation in the supervision and market development 
of accounting services. 
 
(iv)  Knowledge  products  for  researchers,  and  senior  policy  and  decision 
makers. Based on TA outputs, knowledge products, such as policy and technical 
notes that target researchers and policy and decision makers, will be produced. 
The knowledge  products  will  cover  the  issues  on  integration  of  public  asset 
management and budget management, public finance policy framework for the 
water resource management system, and development of accounting services.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $900,000, of which $750,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The government will 
provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff,  office  supplies,  domestic 
transportation, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  MOF’s International Department will be the executing agency. The TA will have three 
implementing  agencies:  (i)  MOF’s  Administrative  and  Law  Enforcement  Department  for 
component 1, (ii) MOF’s Agriculture Department for component 2, and (iii) MOF’s Accounting 
Regulatory  Department  for  component  3.  For  each  of  the  three  components,  an  advisory 
committee will be established comprising representatives from relevant government ministries.

5 
Representatives from Ministry of Water Resources will be included in the committee for the 
second component. 
 
18.  The TA will engage four international consultants and 12 national consultants for a total 
of 92 person-months. Due to the diversity of the three components, a single firm cannot provide 
well-qualified  consultants for the  entire  project.  For  components  1  and  2,  ADB  will  recruit 
international and national consultants on an individual basis; while for component 3, ADB will 
recruit  a  firm  to  provide  one  international  consultant  and  three  national  consultants.  For 
recruitment of a firm, the preferred selection method is quality and cost-based selection with a 
quality–cost  ratio  of  80:20.  If  no  appropriate  firm(s)  can  be  identified  for  component  3, 
consultants  will  be  recruited  on  an  individual  basis.  ADB  will  engage  the  consultants  in 
accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time).  The  TA  proceeds  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  the  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The advance payment facility 
can be used for equipment, seminars, workshops, and conferences. 
 
19.  The TA is expected to begin on 1 November 2012 and be completed by 31 October 
2014. Assembling TA consultant teams and setting detailed work plans will be completed by 
December 2012. Analysis of the current status of budget management and accounting services 
will be completed by March 2013. Workshops, seminars, and international study tours will be 
organized from April to October 2013. Final reports will be delivered during March–May 2014. 
Based  on  the  TA  results,  knowledge  products  such  as  policy  and  technical  notes  will  be 
produced by August 2014. 
 
20.  In addition to the main outputs, the consultants will submit the following reports to ADB 
and MOF’s International Department: (i) inception reports 2 weeks after commencement of their 
services,  (ii) interim  progress  reports  at  an  appropriate  stage  during  TA  implementation,  
(iii) draft final reports before the conclusion of the contract, and (iv) final reports 2 weeks after 
receiving comments from the International Department and ADB. All reports must be submitted 
in English. 
 
21.  The International Department and ADB review missions will regularly monitor and report 
on major project activities. Consultant reports will be presented at workshops and seminars 
organized to validate findings. Reports will be made available on the ADB website in English, if 
appropriate, and published whenever appropriate. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis to 
 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Improvement of Fiscal Management and 
Accounting Services Supervision, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Component  1:  Study  for  Strengthening  the  Integration  of  Public  Asset 
Management and Budget Management 
 
1.  International public finance and budget management specialist (1 person-month, 
intermittent). The specialist must possess good knowledge of and sufficient experience in areas 
related  to  public  finance,  fiscal  policymaking,  and  budget  management;  and  should  have  
(i)  expertise  in  public  finance  theory,  public  expenditure  management,  and  budget  reform 
including output-based budgeting and zero-based budgeting; (ii) a strong academic background, 
with publishing experience of relevant materials; (iii) more than 10 years of experience in related 
areas; and (iv) a graduate degree. Specific tasks include: 
 
(i)  provide support to the advisory committee on research topics, in particular related 
to international trends in public finance and budget management theory and 
practice; 
(ii)  support the establishment of research groups and selection of qualified national 
consultants; 
(iii)  provide continuous advice to national public finance specialists and research 
groups on research topics, materials, and tools, including relevant literature; 
(iv)  adapt lessons from international trends in public finance theory and practice to 
specific conditions in the People’s Republic of China (PRC); 
(v)  provide  advice  to  national  consultants  related  to  developing  policy 
recommendations on public finance and budget management reform; 
(vi)  contribute directly to the preparation of policy reports and provide a final review of 
those reports; 
(vii)  support  arrangements  for  national  and  international  conferences  by  drafting 
agendas, selecting participants, and recommending international experts; and 
(viii)  support arrangements for an international study tour for relevant government 
officials by proposing study areas, host countries, and institutions. 
   
2.  International public asset management specialist (2 person-months, intermittent). 
The specialist must have good knowledge and experience in areas related to public asset 
management and should have (i) expertise in fixed-asset management theory and international 
practice, as well as integration of asset management with budget management; (ii) a strong 
academic background, with publishing experience of relevant materials; (iii) more than 10 years 
of experience in related areas; and (iv) a graduate degree. Specific tasks include: 
 
(i)  provide support to the advisory committee on research topics, in particular related 
to international trends in public asset management theory and practice; 
(ii)  support the establishment of research groups and selection of qualified national 
consultants; 
(iii)  provide continuous advice to national public finance specialists and research 
groups on research topics, materials, and tools, including relevant literature; 
(iv)  adapt lessons of international trends in public asset management theory and 
practice to specific PRC conditions; 
(v)  provide  advice  to  national  consultants  related  to  developing  policy 
recommendations on public asset management and budget reform; 
(vi)  contribute directly to preparation of policy reports and provide a final review of 
those reports; 
(vii)  support  arrangements  for  national  and  international  conferences  by  drafting

(viii)  support arrangements for an international study tour for relevant government

3.  National  public  finance  specialists (four specialists, 35 person-months total). The 
specialists will be experienced researchers from reputable universities or research institutes 
and/or  have  a  background  as  professionals  from  public  authorities.  They  should  have  
(i) theoretical knowledge and expertise in practice in the PRC related to public finance, budget 
management, fiscal policymaking, and public asset management; (ii) more than 5 years of 
experience in related areas; and (iii) a graduate degree. One of the specialists will be appointed 
team  leader.  The  team  leader,  in  cooperation  with  two  international  specialists,  will  be 
responsible  for  quality  control  and  delivering  reports,  including  knowledge  products,  with 
appropriate contributions from the other national specialists. The team leader will be responsible 
for  communication  and  coordination  between  the  executing  agency,  implementing  agency, 
Asian Development Bank (ADB), and the team of consultants. Tasks include: 
 
(i)  review the national and international literature for relevant research topics; 
(ii)  prepare reports on (a) reforming public asset management, (b) developing an 
information system for effective public asset management, and (c) integrating 
public asset management and budget management with help from the advisory 
committee and international specialists; 
(iii)  present and discuss reports with government stakeholders and incorporate their 
comments; 
(iv)  prepare knowledge products based on final reports; and 
(v)  support arrangements for national and international conferences by preparing 
conference  materials,  delivering  presentations,  and  recommending  national 
experts. 
 
B.  Component  2:  Public  Finance  Policy  Framework  for  the  Water  Resource 
Management System 
 
4.  International water resource management specialist (1 person-month, intermittent). 
The specialist must have good knowledge and experience in areas related to scarce resource 
management and should have (i) expertise in water resource management, public finance, and 
fund management; (ii) a strong academic background, with publishing experience of relevant 
materials; (iii) more than 10 years experience in related areas; and (iv) a graduate degree. 
Specific tasks include 
(i)  provide support to the advisory committee on research topics, in particular related 
to international trends in scarce water resource management theory and practice; 
(ii)  support the establishment of research groups and selection of qualified national 
consultants; 
(iii)  provide continuous advice to national environmental and financial management 
specialists  and  research  groups  on  research  topics,  materials,  and  tools, 
including relevant literature; 
(iv)  adapt  lessons on  international  trends  in  scarce  water  resource management 
theory and practice to specific PRC conditions; 
(v)  provide  advice  to  national  consultants  related  to  developing  policy 
recommendations on water resource management; 
(vi)  contribute directly to the preparation of policy reports and provide a final review of 
those reports; 
(vii)  support  arrangements  for  national  and  international  conferences  by  drafting

12  Appendix 3 
agendas, selecting participants, and recommending international experts; and 
(viii)  support arrangements for an international study tour for relevant government 
officials by proposing study areas, host countries, and institutions.  
 
5.  National environmental and financial management specialists (five specialists, 40 
person-months, intermittent). The specialists will be experienced researchers from reputable 
universities  or  research  institutes  and/or  have  a  background  as  professionals  from  public 
authorities. They should have (i) theoretical knowledge and expertise in practice in the PRC 
related to environment economics, resource saving, public finance, and fund management; 
(ii) more than 5 years experience in related areas; and (iii) a graduate degree. One of the 
specialists will be appointed team leader. The team leader, in cooperation with the international 
water resource management specialist, will be responsible for quality control and delivering 
reports, including knowledge products, with appropriate contributions from the other national 
specialists. The team leader will be responsible for communication and coordination between 
the executing agency, implementing agency, ADB, and the team of consultants. Tasks include 
 
(i)  review the national and international literature for relevant research topics; 
(ii)  prepare  reports  on  the  public  finance  policy  framework  for  water  resource 
management,  covering  such  topics  as  (a)  overview  of  the  water  resource 
management system, (b) review of recent technological development related to 
water resource management, (c) review of an investment mechanism for the 
water resource management fund, (d) improvement of the public finance policy 
framework for the water resource management system, and (e) other related 
policy recommendations and regulations; 
(iii)  conduct  a  review  of  experience  from  pilot  projects  of  the  water  resource 
management system in the PRC; 
(iv)  present  and  discuss  the  draft  framework  and  implementing  regulations  with 
stakeholders in the government and incorporate their comments; 
(v)  ensure that the process of the budget allocation for water management will be 
based on the integrated framework of public asset management and  budget 
management developed under the first component; 
(vi)  prepare knowledge products based on final reports; and 
(vii)  support arrangements for national and international conferences by preparing 
conference  materials,  delivering  presentations,  and  recommending  national 
experts. 
 
C.  Component 3: Support for Development of Accounting Services 
 
6.  International  accounting  and  financial  markets  specialist  (3  person-months, 
intermittent). The specialist must have good knowledge and experience in areas related to the 
accounting services, and should have (i) expertise in international accounting and auditing 
standards, and financial market opening and development; (ii) a strong academic background, 
with publishing experience of relevant materials; (iii) more than 10 years of experience in related 
areas; and (iv) a graduate degree. Specific tasks include 
 
(i)  provide support to the advisory committee on research topics, in particular related 
to international trends in accounting and auditing standards, market integration, 
and supervisory collaboration; 
(ii)  support the establishment of research groups; 
(iii)  provide continuous advice to national accounting and financial policy specialists 
and research groups on research topics, materials, and tools, including relevant

Appendix 3  13 
literature; 
(iv)  adapt lessons from international trends in accounting services to specific PRC 
conditions; 
(v)  provide  advice  to  national  consultants  related  to  developing  policy 
recommendations on strengthening the convergence of the PRC accounting and 
auditing standards with international standards, opening accounting services, and 
developing certified public accountants; 
(vi)  contribute directly to preparation of policy reports and provide a final review of 
those reports; 
(vii)  support  arrangements  for  national  and  international  conferences  by  drafting 
agendas, selecting participants, and recommending international experts; and 
(viii)  support  arrangements  for  international  study  tours  for  relevant  government 
officials by proposing study areas, host countries, and institutions. 
 
7.  National accounting and financial policy specialists (three specialists, 10 person-
months,  intermittent).  The  specialists  will  be  experienced  researchers  from  reputable 
universities  or  research  institutes  and/or  have  a  background  as  professionals  from  public 
authorities. They should have (i) theoretical knowledge and expertise in practice in the PRC 
related to accounting and auditing standards, and financial market opening and development 
policies; (ii) more than 5 years experience in related areas; and (iii) a graduate degree. One of 
the  specialists  will  be  appointed  team  leader.  The  team  leader,  in  cooperation  with  the 
international accounting and financial market specialist, will be responsible for quality control 
and delivering reports, including knowledge products, with appropriate contributions from the 
other  national  specialists.  The  team  leader  will  be  responsible  for  communication  and 
coordination  between  the  executing  agency,  implementing  agency,  ADB,  and  the  team  of 
consultants. Tasks include 
 
(i)  review the national and international literature for relevant research topics; 
(ii)  prepare reports on opening and developing accounting services, covering such 
topics as (a) convergence of the PRC accounting and auditing standards with 
international  standards,  (b)  international  collaboration  in  supervision  of 
accounting services, and (c) development of certified public accountants in the 
PRC; 
(iii)  present  and  discuss  the  draft  framework  and  implementing  regulations  with 
government stakeholders and incorporate their comments; 
(iv)  prepare knowledge products based on final reports; and 
(v)  support arrangements for national and international conferences by preparing 
conference  materials,  delivering  presentations,  and  recommending  national 
experts. 
 
D.  Reporting Requirements 
 
8.  The national team leaders, in cooperation with the international consultants, will be 
responsible for delivering reports, with appropriate contributions from the other experts. The 
national team leader for each component will submit (i) an inception report 1 month after the 
start of their services, (ii) an interim report 2–5 months after TA inception, (iii) a draft final report 
4 weeks before conclusion of the contract, and (iv) a final report within 2 weeks after comments 
are received from the executing agency, implementing agencies, and ADB.
